thread.title: Member of British Parliament who tried to save officer born in NYC
thread.title_full: Member of British Parliament who tried to save officer born in NYC | New York Post

author: Natalie Musumeci
title: Member of British Parliament who tried to save officer born in NYC
text:
A New York City-born member of the British Parliament led the effort to try to save the police officer fatally stabbed in Wednesday’s London terror attack .
Tobias Ellwood, Britain’s Minister for the Middle East and a reserve solider, can be seen in photos splattered with blood as he performed CPR on the officer , Keith Palmer, 48, in the courtyard grounds of Parliament.
“[He] tried to give mouth-to-mouth and stem blood flow from multiple stab wounds to the officer until the chopper and medics arrived,” a source close to Ellwood told The Telegraph.
Ellwood’s friend, MP Adam Afriyie, told the BBC he saw Ellwood heading to the scene even though police said stay away. Photos of Ellwood, a 50-year-old Army Reserve officer, show him aiding the stabbed Palmer in a business suit with blood on his hands and forehead.
Keith Palmer Met Police Ellwood, a dad of two, was born in New York in 1966 to parents who were living here while serving as UK officials. He lost his 37-year-old brother in a terrorist attack in Bali in 2002, according to reports.
He has been a Conservative Member of Parliament for Bournemouth East in the south of England since 2005.
Ellwood was lauded on social media for his bold action.
“@Tobias_Ellwood is an absolute hero for what he did to help the policeman this afternoon!” Ben Howlett, the MP for Bath, tweeted.
“Today, Tobias gave MPs a good name. He was utterly heroic, pure and simple,” added Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron.
Palmer was among five people killed, including the assailant, and 40 injured in the attack.
